article.headline: Colorado State 78, Regis College 49
article.story: FORT COLLINS, Colo. (AP) -- No Matt Nelson? No problem. With Matt Nelson, last year's leading scorer, limited by concern for his knees, Colorado State turned to the young, Jason Smith. Smith, a freshman, picked up the slack with 13 points, three rebounds and two blocked shots as Colorado State (1-0) to beat Regis 78-49 in its regular season opener Saturday night. "I'm not playing him just for fun," Colorado State coach Dale Layer said about Smith. "This is a guy that contributed 18-20 minutes in our exhibition games and has proven he can play." This from a 7-foot, 18-year-old, who weighed less than 200 pounds and was attending the school prom at Platte Valley High School in rural eastern Colorado five months earlier. "There is a difference in me as a freshman here," Smith said. "I worked in the weight room over the summer, added over 25 pounds and got myself ready to play." He displayed his skills along with Matt Williams, who had 20 points and five rebounds in the game, in a 19-0 second half run that put the game out of reach for Colorado State. Williams shot 8-for-10 and 4-of-6 from the free throw line. Nelson scored only six points in 10 minutes of play. "I wasn't happy with Matt Nelson," Layer said. "And you always want to protect a guy like him this early in the season. Austin Christensen led Regis (0-1) with 19 points and six rebounds. Regis shot 35 percent and fell to Colorado State for the 10th consecutive time. With Christensen accounting for its first nine points, and Colorado State shooting a woeful 50 percent from the free throw line, Regis stayed close for the first 14 minutes of the game. Ben Schafer's hook shot got Regis to within one at 15-14. But the Rams closed the half with a 19-3 run to take 34-17 lead at the break. Regis started the second half with a 7-0 run to pull to within 10 points, but Colorado State then went on its 19-0 run. Part of the run included a full court length drive by Smith. "The guy does things most 7-footers can't do," Layer said. But then, Smith said he doesn't think of himself as a 7-footer. "The stereotyped 7-footer is a guy that has to bend over in a crouch just to dribble. I don't have any trouble dribbling the ball at all."
